topics.title: Introduction
content: Mathematical Logic is the study of rules and principles of reasoning.
It helps check whether a statement is true or false using logical rules.
Mainly used in computer science for programming, algorithms, and proofs.
Example: 'If it rains, then the ground is wet.'

topics.title: Connectives
content: AND ( ∧ ) → True only if both are True.
OR ( ∨ ) → True if at least one is True.
NOT ( ¬ ) → Opposite of the statement.
IF–THEN ( → ) → False only when first is True and second is False.
IF AND ONLY IF ( ↔ ) → True when both are same (both True or both False).

topics.title: Negation
content: Negation means opposite of a statement.
If a statement is True, its negation is False and vice versa.
Symbol: ¬p
Example: p = 'It is raining', ¬p = 'It is NOT raining'

topics.title: Conjunction
content: Combining two statements with AND ( ∧ ).
True only if both statements are True.
Symbol: p ∧ q
Example: 'I study AND I pass.'

topics.title: Disjunction
content: Combining two statements with OR ( ∨ ).
True if at least one statement is True.
Symbol: p ∨ q
Example: 'I study OR I play.'

topics.title: Conditional
content: If–Then statement.
False only when first is True and second is False.
Symbol: p → q
Example: 'If I study, then I pass.'

topics.title: Bi-conditional
content: If and only if ( ↔ ).
True when both statements have same truth value.
Symbol: p ↔ q
Example: 'I study if and only if I pass.'

topics.title: Statement Formulas
content: Combination of statements + connectives.
Built using variables (p, q, r...), logical connectives, and brackets.
Examples: ¬p, (p ∧ q) → r, (p ∨ ¬q) ↔ (r ∧ s)

topics.title: Tautology and Contradiction
content: Tautology: always True. Example: p ∨ ¬p
Contradiction: always False. Example: p ∧ ¬p

topics.title: Equivalence Formulae
content: Two formulas are equivalent if they always give same truth values.
Common equivalences:
Double Negation: ¬(¬p) ≡ p
Implication: (p → q) ≡ (¬p ∨ q)
Contrapositive: (p → q) ≡ (¬q → ¬p)
De Morgan’s Laws: ¬(p ∧ q) ≡ (¬p ∨ ¬q), ¬(p ∨ q) ≡ (¬p ∧ ¬q)
Biconditional: (p ↔ q) ≡ (p → q) ∧ (q → p)

topics.title: Normal Forms
content: Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF/PDNF): OR of AND terms. Example: (p ∧ q) ∨ (¬p ∧ r)
Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF/PCNF): AND of OR terms. Example: (p ∨ q) ∧ (¬p ∨ r)

topics.title: Principal Normal Forms
content: PDNF: OR of all minterms where formula is True.
Example: (p ∨ q) → PDNF = (p ∧ ¬q) ∨ (¬p ∧ q) ∨ (p ∧ q)
PCNF: AND of all maxterms where formula is False.
Example: (p ∨ q) → PCNF = (p ∨ q)

topics.title: Theory of Inferences using Truth Tables
content: Inference = drawing conclusion from premises.
Valid if conclusion is True whenever premises are True.
Steps: write premises & conclusion, make truth table, check validity.
Example (Modus Ponens): Premises: (p → q), p → Conclusion: q
